source.title: Evaluation of a Caterpillar 535B grapple skidder in a second-growth forest in coastal British Columbia
source.region: Englewood (13 km south of Port McNeill), northern Vancouver Island, BC
source.operations_summary: Caterpillar 535B grapple skidder supporting a loader-forwarding/roadside-processing system across clearcut-with-retention bands (CWHvm1) on 5–25% slopes.

site.terrain: Hummocky benches with short steep pitches (0–40% slopes).
site.decking_strategy: Skidder decks when space allows; loader-forwarder or hot processing clears roads in confined sections.

machine.name: Caterpillar 535B grapple skidder
machine.tires: 35.5L-32 (0.9 m wide) with ring chains on both axles
attachments: Dual-function arch (2.89 m reach past rear axle)
Hydraulic bunching grapple with 3.1 m opening / 1.34 m² accumulation
support_equipment: Denharco stroke delimbers on Cat 322C excavators
Risley TK-1162 feller-buncher with Rotosaw HF2229 head
machine.crew_notes: Single-shift skidder (5 days/week) paired with loader-forwarder (7 days/week) and hot-processing stroke delimbers.

variables.CT: Cycle time from the selected cycle-time equation (min)

combined_cost.equation: CS+D = (SC + LC * SR) / (SPUS * (1 - SR) + SPS * SR)

variables.SR: Loader support ratio (0 = skidder decks itself, 1 = loader decks full-time)
variables.SPUS: Skidder productivity when decking its own turns (m³/SMH)

combined_cost.notes: Loader support ratio represents the share of the skidder’s work shift that requires the loader-forwarder to re-pile stems. In the case study, a 0.4 ratio (4 h of loader support per 10 h skidder shift) dropped total extraction cost to ~57% of loader-forwarding alone.

costs.assumptions: Costs derived from FERIC Appendix I (0.90 CAD/L diesel, 51% wage loading, 8.5 h skidder shift, 10 h loader-forwarder shift). Indirect costs excluded.

soil_disturbance.survey_method: BC FPC soil conservation guidebook transects (2 375 points).
soil_disturbance.mitigation_notes: Moderately dry soils, 0.9 m tires with chains, and loader-forwarder re-decking limited rutting; wet depressions still showed deep ruts.

notes: Total harvested volume was 20 343 m³; the Caterpillar 535B handled 16 179 m³ while a Morgan SX-706 SB skidder covered 952 m³ of short shifts.
Most skidding was uphill on 5–25% slopes with travel distances up to 300 m; loader-forwarder pre-positioned bunches beyond 60 m or on steep backline benches.
Average bunch prepared by the feller-buncher contained 4.7 stems; skidder payloads of two or more bunches were rare because bunch size already matched grapple capacity.
Skidding/l deck coordination (hot processing, loader-supported decking, or alternating short/long pulls) minimized deck congestion and kept skidder utilization near 93%.

Recommended planning limits: keep grapple skidder distances below ~250–300 m, avoid uphill skidding on gentle slopes when downhill corridors exist, and reserve moist/fine-textured pockets for loader-forwarding or dry-season skidding.
